text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

IRM 5.17.7.1.1 - incorporated additional potentially responsible parties from SB-SE-05-0711-044, Interim Guidance for Conducting Trust Fund Recovery Penalty Investigations in Cases Involving a Third-Party Payer.

This supersedes IRM 5.17.7 dated August 1, 2010. This IRM incorporates Interim Guidance SB-SE-05-0711-044, Interim Guidance for Conducting Trust Fund Recovery Penalty Investigations in Involving a Third-Party Payer, 7/1/2011.
Liability of Third Parties for Unpaid Employment
of Third Parties for Unpaid Employment Taxes 5.17.7 page

provides that whenever any person is required to collect or withhold any internal revenue taxes from any other person and to pay over Recovery such tax to the United States, the amount of the tax shall be held in a trust fund for the United States. Trust fund taxes include employment taxes and certain types of excise taxes. (
) The Trust Fund Recovery Penalty (TFRP) is based on IRC §
and certain types of excise taxes. (
) The Trust Fund Recovery Penalty (TFRP) is based on IRC §

(a), which provides as follows: “Any person required to collect, truthfully account for, and pay over any tax by this title who willfully fails to collect such tax, or truthfully account for and pay over such tax, or willfully attempts in any manner to evade or defeat any such tax on the payment thereof, shall, in addition to other penalties provided by law, be liable to a penalty equal to the total amount of the tax evaded, or not collected, or not accounted for and paid over. No penalty shall be imposed under section
or part II of subchapter A of chapter
for any offense to which this section is cable.” (
) It encourages prompt payment of income and employment taxes withheld from employees and other collected taxes; (cid:
) It makes the responsible person liable for
% of the unpaid trust fund taxes; and (cid:
) It facilitates collection of trust fund taxes from secondary sources. (
) A person is liable for the TFRP if two statutory requirements are met: (cid:
) The person is “responsible” — had the duty to account for, collect, and pay over the trust fund taxes to the government; and (cid:
) The person “willfully” failed to collect or pay over trust fund taxes to the government. (
) The Service may collect trust fund taxes only once, whether from the from one or more of its responsible persons, or from the business and one or more responsible persons. (
includes, but is not limited to, the following: (cid:
) Officer or employee of a corporation; (cid:
) Partner or employee of a partnership; (cid:
) Member or employee of an LLC; (cid:

) Responsible parties within the common law employer (client of PSP/PEO) Note: The TFRP is not needed to assert liability against the owner of a sole etorship because the individual owner is personally liable for employment

by this title who willfully fails to collect such tax, or truthfully account for and pay over such tax, or willfully attempts in any manner to evade or defeat any such tax on the payment thereof, shall, in addition to other penalties provided by law, be liable to a penalty equal to the total amount of the tax evaded, or not collected, or not accounted for and paid over. No penalty shall be imposed under section 6653 or part II of subchapter A of chapter 68 for any offense to which this section is appli- cable.”
The term “person” in Section 6672 includes, but is not limited to, the following:
(07-18-2012) Persons Subject to the Trust Fund Recovery Penalty
Note: The TFRP is not needed to assert liability against the owner of a sole propri- etorship because the individual owner is personally liable for employment
5.17 Legal Reference Guide for Revenue Officers
Legal Reference Guide for Revenue taxes under IRC §§
However, the TFRP may be needed to assert liability against an employee or other non-owner who exercises control over the finances. (

) Regardless of a person’s corporate title, a person will not be held liable for TFRP unless he or she has the duty to account for, collect, and pay over the trust fund taxes to the government. Even an officer of the business will not a responsible person if he or she is an officer in title only and has no tive duties with the business. O’Connor v. United States,
). On the other hand, a person who has no corporate title but has of financial affairs or controls payment of funds by the business, may be held responsible for the TFRP. (
) A determination of liability must take into account all facts and circumstances. (
) Most TFRP cases involve corporate officers. (

) A director who is not an officer or employee of the corporation may be sible for the TFRP if he or she was responsible for the corporation’s failure to pay taxes that were due and owing. Commonwealth Nat’l Bank of Dallas v. United States,
(b), a member of a partnership, Limited Company (LLC), or Limited Liability Partnership (LLP) may be liable for the TFRP. (

) As a general rule, general partners are individually liable under state law for the debts of a partnership; therefore, assessments are made in the name of the partnership and the names of the general partners. Accordingly, there is usually no reason to make a separate TFRP assessment against the various partners. United States v. Galletti,

). In a limited liability partnership, however, general partners may not be individually liable for the debts of the partnership, depending on the jurisdiction. If you determine that the general partners are not individually liable for the debts of the partnership under state law, then a TFRP assessment against one or more partners may be appropriate. Contact Advisory or Area Counsel with any questions. (
) An employee may be liable for the TFRP if he or she made the decision not pay the taxes due. Gephart v. United States,

) Employees are generally under the dominion and control of an employer; however, instructions from a supervisor not to pay taxes do not relieve an employee who is an otherwise “responsible person” from IRC §
) Allegations that an employee is a responsible person should be thoroughly vestigated. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
) An employee may be liable for the TFRP if he or she made the decision not pay the taxes due. Gephart v. United States,

) Employees are generally under the dominion and control of an employer; however, instructions from a supervisor not to pay taxes do not relieve an employee who is an otherwise “responsible person” from IRC §
) Allegations that an employee is a responsible person should be thoroughly in-

) Professional Employer Organizations (PEOs), sometimes also referred to employee leasing companies, and their owners, officers, and/or employees Employer may be responsible persons with respect to client organizations in certain (PEOs) limited circumstances. If you have a case in which you believe that a PEO an owner, officer, and/or employee of a PEO may be a responsible person, contact Area Counsel. (

) A responsible person may be held liable for the TFRP if such person fails to perform any one of the three duties listed in the statute: collecting, truthfully accounting for, and paying over the taxes. Slodov v. United States,
) The statute does not impose upon the responsible person an absolute duty pay over amounts that should have been collected and withheld by prior re- sponsible persons. Slodov v. United States,

b. ) The crucial test is whether the person has the “effective power to pay the taxes owed.” Purcell v. United States ,

). A person is deemed to have such power if he or she possesses the authority to exercise significant control over the company’s financial affairs whether or not such control is in fact exercised. Purcell at
Significant control generally relates to the person’s status, duty, and authority in the business that failed to carry out one of the three statutory duties. Davis v. United States,
) Those performing ministerial duties without exercising independent judgment will not be deemed responsible. See Policy Statement

) An unpaid, voluntary board member of a tax-exempt organization will not be considered a responsible person if the board member is solely serving in an honorary capacity, does not participate in the day-to-day or financial of the business, and does not have actual knowledge of the failure on which the penalty is based. IRC §

(e). This exception, however, does not apply it results in no person being liable for the TFRP. Also, a voluntary board member of a tax-exempt organization who is intimately involved in the decisions of the company may be a responsible person. See Jefferson v. United States,

The circuits that have decided the issue have split on whether “reasonable cause” negates a responsible person’s willfulness and is a defense to TFRP liability.
cause” negates a responsible person’s willfulness and is a defense to liability. a. The Eighth and First Circuits have determined that reasonable cause not a defense. Olsen v. United States,

). b. The Ninth Circuit has not stated specifically that the reasonable defense does not apply; however, it has determined that “conduct motivated by a reasonable cause may, nonetheless, be willful.” United States,
). c. The Tenth, Eleventh, Second, and Fifth Circuits have determined that reasonable cause defense applies, at least conceptually, to terminations under Section
Even these circuits, however, apply defense narrowly. Smith v. United States,

) Bank records and canceled checks should be examined for payment of financial obligations after the taxes became due. a. Signature cards should identify the persons authorized to sign checks. b. Bank records may disclose possible diversion of corporate funds.

c. Generally, the TFRP must be assessed within three years after the to which it relates was filed. Lauckner v. United States,

). d. A return of withholding and FICA taxes filed on or before the due date is deemed to have been filed on the due date. Thus, with to any taxable period within a calendar year, the period of limitations is three years from the succeeding April

(the due date of the return) or the date the return was filed, whichever is later. e. A return executed by the revenue officer is not considered the and, therefore, does not start the assessment statute. f. If the return is fraudulent, the tax may be assessed at any time. (
) The assessment period may be extended prior to its expiration by the of the person against whom the penalty is to be assessed. This extension, however, applies only to the consenting officer. (

Generally, the TFRP must be assessed within three years after the return to which it relates was filed. Lauckner v. United States, 68 F.3d 69 (3d Cir.

Under IRC § 6672(b)(3), the assessment statute may be extended when the IRS mails or hand delivers the L-1153, Notice of Proposed Trust Fund Recovery Penalty, to the taxpayer. Specifically, IRC § 6672(b)(3) provides that if the assessment statute is open when the Service mails or delivers in the L-1153 to a responsible person, the assessment statute shall not expire before the later of the following dates:
and supporting documents were mailed or hand delivered to the responsible person, or (cid:
) If the person files a timely protest of the proposed TFRP, the date
days after Appeals makes a “final administrative determination ” regarding the proposed penalty.

EXAMPLE: The limitations period for assessing the TFRP against the taxpayer will expire on April 15, 2010. The revenue officer hand delivers the L-1153 to the taxpayer on April 1, 2010. Because the assessment statute was open when the L-1153 was delivered to the taxpayer, the statute is extended to the date that is 90 days after April 1, 2010 (which is June 30, 2010), unless the taxpayer files a timely protest. If the taxpayer files a timely protest, then the assessment statute will not expire until the date that is 30 days after Appeals makes a final determination regarding the proposed penalty, assuming that date is after June 30, 2010.

In some cases, lenders, sureties, or other persons who are not employers may be personally liable for withheld taxes due. While employers are primarily liable for paying withheld taxes, in some cases they may be without sufficient resources to pay. As a result, recourse against them may be fruitless. IRC §
may provide an alternative means of collecting the withheld taxes.
Third Parties for Unpaid Employment Taxes
(a) makes third parties personally liable for the payment of with- holding taxes where they pay wages directly to employees of another. (

(a) applies to lenders, sureties, or other persons. – IRC a. “Other persons” includes anyone similar to a lender or surety who pays the wages of employees of another out of its own funds. The most common situation in which a person other than a lender or surety (a statutory “other person”) may be found liable under IRC §

(a) is where a prime or general contractor, out of necessity (to keep the employees of the subcontractor on the job) or by contract, pays net directly to employees of a subcontractor that is having financial See United States v. Kennedy Construction Co. of NSB, Inc.,
(a) liability imposed on a general contractor who co-signed payroll checks for a subcontractor’s employees). b. IRC §
(a) does not apply to a person who is acting only as agent of the employer or as agent of the employees (such as a union agent). See Treas. Reg. §
) Liability does not extend to the employer’s share of employment taxes; nor does liability extend to penalties that the Service may impose on the (

(a) does not relieve an employer from responsibilities with respect to withholding taxes. The responsibilities continue even though a lender may be paying the employees’ wages. The liability of the lender in such a case is pay the taxes only where the employer does not do so. a. The employer is obligated to file an employer’s tax return (Form

) comply with other requirements generally imposed on employers. b. The lender’s liability is a sum equal to the taxes (together with interest) required to be deducted and withheld from the wages by the employer. (

) When evaluating whether wages are being paid directly, the Service and the courts look to the “substance” of the transaction and may find the direct payment of net wages present even though a “ subterfuge” is used to the substance of the arrangement. See United States v. Kennedy Co. of NSB, Inc.,

) (subcontractor opened payroll account out of which it issued payroll checks; however, the contractor provided the funds in the account after verifying the net wages owed each period and countersigned the pay checks). (

(b) provides that a lender, surety, or other person who supplies funds to or for the account of an employer for the specific purpose of paying Funds are wages of the employees of such employer may be personally liable for any § unpaid withholding taxes even though this person does not directly pay the employees’ wages. of Third Parties for Unpaid Employment Taxes 5.17.7
IRC § 3505(a) makes third parties personally liable for the payment of with- holding taxes where they pay wages directly to employees of another.
§ 3505(a) applies to lenders, sureties, or other persons.
Liability does not extend to the employer’s share of employment taxes; nor does liability extend to penalties that the Service may impose on the employer.

IRC § 3505(b) provides that a lender, surety, or other person who supplies funds to or for the account of an employer for the specific purpose of wages of the employees of such employer may be personally liable for any unpaid withholding taxes even though this person does not directly pay the
A person within the meaning of Section 3505(b) includes the following:
5.17 Legal Reference Guide for Revenue Officers
) A prime or general contractor who supplies funds directly to a to meet its net payroll with knowledge of the subcontractor’s inability to its withholding taxes. United States. Algernon Blair, Inc.,

) A shareholder, including a parent company of a subsidiary, who makes capital contribution or a direct loan, or who puts up collateral for a loan from a third party to a corporation if the loan is to be used by the tion to pay net wages. United States v. Intercontinental Industries, Inc., F.
) A bank that honors a customer’s/employer’s overdrafts for payroll Fidelity Bank, N.A. v. United States,

(b), the following two tions must exist. a. The person must know that the advanced funds are to be used for the payment of wages; this does not include an “ordinary working capital loan.” “Ordinary working capital loans” are ones that are made to the borrower to meet current obligations as they arise; they are not earmarked for any particular purpose. , provides that every performance bond on federal construction projects shall specifically guarantee payment of federal payroll taxes. The obligation of the surety on the performance bond must guarantee the payment of taxes that are required to be collected, deducted, withheld from wages by the contractor, whether or not the contractor does in fact collect, deduct, or withhold such taxes. (
) Notice of Unpaid Taxes a. The government must notify the surety of any unpaid taxes attributable any period within
days after the date when the contractor in fact files return for such period. b. If the contractor fails to file a timely return, the Service must give notice the surety no later than

days from the date when such return was required to be filed, whether or not such return was ever filed. c. The notice requirements apply to each calendar quarter or other taxable period. The following examples illustrate the notice requirement periods:
) The contractor on a federal construction project files a Form

(11-02-2007) Liability of Sureties — Bond on Public Works Contracts
a. The government must notify the surety of any unpaid taxes attributable to any period within
days after the date when the contractor in fact files a return for such period. b. If the contractor fails to file a timely return, the Service must give notice to the surety no later than

days from the date when such return was required to be filed, whether or not such return was ever filed. c. The notice requirements apply to each calendar quarter or other taxable period. The following examples illustrate the notice requirement periods:
) The contractor on a federal construction project files a Form

) The government may offset any funds still due the prime contractor. In this case, because of the limited time in which notice can be given to the surety, the revenue officer should still consider notifying the surety for the purpose of holding the surety liable under the provisions of the Miller Act. (

) The only way other than offset to collect is by bringing suit against the surety within one year after the day on which timely notice of the unpaid tax liability was given to the surety. Example: If the surety is given timely notice on July
, that the contractor failed to pay over the taxes applicable to a taxable period, the govern- ment must commence suit on or before July
, to enforce the obligation under the performance bond. Because of this short statute of limitations, the revenue officer should be alert for the necessity of action. (

) The government will continue to assert its rights under a surety bond on than federal construction projects, but only where the available evidence clearly and convincingly shows the bond was intended for the direct benefit

The government may offset any funds still due the prime contractor. In this case, because of the limited time in which notice can be given to the surety, the revenue officer should still consider notifying the surety for the purpose of holding the surety liable under the provisions of the Miller Act.
Example: If the surety is given timely notice on July
, that the contractor failed to pay over the taxes applicable to a taxable period, the govern- ment must commence suit on or before July
, to enforce the obligation under the performance bond. Because of this short statute of limitations, the revenue officer should be alert for the necessity of action. (

) The government will continue to assert its rights under a surety bond on other than federal construction projects, but only where the available evidence clearly and convincingly shows the bond was intended for the direct benefit of the United States.
